prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for telling my girlfriend she doesn’t need to make plans every time I want to game?
My girlfriend and I have been living together for 4 months now. We’ve been together for 3 years, and I’ve loved every minute of it and we absolutely adore each other.

When we first got together I gave up a lot of my free time for dates and other couple things like that. 

We would spend the night together sometimes. But when we would go home alone, to our respective houses. I would use that time to get my game time in.

Now flash forward, we live together and are obviously spending more time together. 

It all started a few weeks ago after work, when my buddy messaged me and asked me to get on and play Apex Legends, I say yeah, and tell my girlfriend I’m gonna play some games if she doesn’t mind. Up until that point we only used my Xbox as an entertainment system ( think Hulu, YouTube and Netflix.) 

I had previously taken a pretty long break from games and I didn’t expect this to be her reaction.

She said, it’s not fair for me to play games because she has nothing else to do while we play. I said, well you can watch me play jokingly, I thought she was kidding at first, but then she continued and said if I wanna make plans then to let her know so she can be busy while I’m busy. She also said she missed me. I told her we could have time for just us when I was done playing, and that it wasn’t a “plan.” I’m not going anywhere, I’ll be right here. I even told her we could talk while I played. But she didn’t want to have any of it. She just went to her sisters house for a few hours, and I proceeded to get some dubs.

Then, it became an argument we had 2-3 times. I even gave her advanced notice on an occasion or two but If she failed to make her plan she blamed it on me. So I told her ‘she didn’t need to go out every time, I’m busy. Just relax and chill on your phone or use my laptop.’ 

She’s the kinda girl who wants constant attention and I am fine with that, but I also want to chill with my friends online and play. 

AITA?

Tl;dr Girlfriend wants me to preplan my gaming time so she can make plans to go out. I said she doesn’t need to go out just because I wanna play games.
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, so I need to figure out if the author is in the wrong here. Let me read through the situation again to make sure I understand it.

The user (the author) is in a relationship with his girlfriend. They've been together three years and live together now. Initially, he gave up a lot of his free time for dates and couple activities. When they were apart, he used that time to game. Now that they live together, when he wants to game, he tells her and she gets upset because she feels she has nothing to do while he's playing. He tried suggesting she watch him play or use her phone, but she left to go to her sister's. They had arguments about this, and he told her she doesn't need to make plans every time he wants to game. The question is whether the author is in the wrong (A or B).

First, I need to consider both sides. The author wants to game with friends, which is a personal activity. The girlfriend feels neglected and wants to be involved or have her own plans. 

In relationships, communication and mutual respect are key. The author mentions that he's okay with her wanting attention but also wants time to game. However, the girlfriend's reaction suggests that she feels her needs aren't being met. The author's approach of telling her she doesn't need to make plans might come off as dismissive of her feelings. Even though he offered alternatives (watching, using her phone), she didn't want that. 

The problem arises when the author downplays her need for engagement. By saying she doesn't need to make plans, he might be invalidating her feelings of missing him and wanting to spend time together. Healthy relationships require compromise. The author could be in the wrong if he's not acknowledging her emotional needs. However, it's also about balance; everyone has personal time. 

But the key here is that the girlfriend is feeling left out. The author's gaming time isn't inherently wrong, but if it's causing her distress and he's not addressing her feelings adequately, then he might be at fault. The fact that she left multiple times and he responded by telling her she doesn't need to go out might not be fostering a solution. Instead of dismissing her, maybe he should have discussed finding a middle ground. 

So, considering all that, the author might be in the wrong for not taking her feelings into account properly and not being flexible. The answer could be A. But I need to check if there's any nuance I missed. The author tried to communicate, but perhaps not effectively. The girlfriend's need for attention is valid, and the author's refusal to adjust might be an issue. Therefore, A (the author is in the wrong) seems correct.
